summary.p: This folio is part of an assortment of three fragments found with Sanscrit 1347. This fragment is only written on the verso side, containing an excerpt from the seventh chapter of the Ṣaṭsāhasrasaṃhitā, a Śākta tantric text. The text seems to continue directly after Sanscrit 1442.6, presenting the beginning of a śabdarāśi — an enumeration of the 50 syllables of the Sanskrit alphabet, each associated with a manifestation of Śiva as well as with a part of the body.

On the recto side, a note by Palmyr Cordier gives the title Kulālikāmnaya tantra. This fragment was likely copied from a photograph (see item 4b, Filliozat 1934, 17) of a famous manuscript that was discovered by Haraprasāda Śāstrī in Nepal and brought to Calcutta. He dated the manuscript to the 7th century, but later scholars have revised that estimate to the 12th century (van Kooij 1975).
The fragment has parallels to a similar passage in the text of the Kubjikāmatatantra published by Goudriaan & Schoterman (1988, 442-443) as well as to Agnipurāṇa 145 (ed. Mitra 1876, 103).
